properties.comments: High value habitat. Low densities of fish (not sure why). Abundant gravels, deep pools, undercut banks, and small woody debris. Extreme areas of algal growth. Cattle impacts extreme throughout.
Same site length as last year. See gps track. Electrofished and Edna sampled.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Fished from approximately 35m downstream of bridge up to the middle of the bridge. Stop net at the bottom. Exact same site as 2024. Bottom of site wp 430.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Fished the exact same site as 2024. Started roughly 50m downstream of the bridge and worked our way up to the middle of the bridge. Bottom of site marked with flagging. Fish pit tagged over 65mm.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Fished from middle of bridge upstream to where channel splits into two. Roughly 50m. Top of site marked with flagging.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Entire site was mostly dewatered with only 3-4 spots even fishable. One fish captured in deepest “pool” (see pool photo).
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Site is intermittently dewatered with significantly less water than in 2024. Still many fish caught - all in deepest pool located on left bank approximately 3m upstream of the flagging. Total area wetted was estimated at 5m squared.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Time for widths should be discarded since surveyor did not have the gps on.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Fished the outlet pool. This is the same site as 2024. Electrofishing was conducted and fish 60mm or more were PIT tagged. Slightly less water than last year.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Wetland located ~80m downstream. Good flow.  Abundant gravels for 30-40m downstream of culvert.  eDNA sample collected.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Low gradient stream with significant riparian tree blow down throughout. Very difficult walking so most was done outside of the active channel with spot visits to the stream for measurements/photos completed intermittently for the 600m that was assessed. Wide floodplain within well defined canyon (approximately 15m deep with slopes of ~45°). Healthy riparian, consisting of herb and shrub cover within sparse spruce forest that appears to have been impacted by some sort of beetle or other affliction. Most of the spruce trees were dead with many already fallen down.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Very nice stream with good flow. Significant precipitation last night so could be running higher than typical for this time of year. Abundant gravels throughout and abundant cover in numerous forms present. No barriers observed. EDNA sample taken at bottom end of site.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Surveyed 350m upstream to the beginning of the wetlands. Very nice stream with good flow, although recent rainfall may have had an influence. Pockets of gravels throughout the area surveyed. Although the area viewed was limited, the wetlands appeared shallow so freezing to the bottom may occur during the winter.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Large stream with complex habitat and diverse cover including deep pools, boulders, large and small woody debris, and undercut banks. A canyon section approximately 100m long was located 100m upstream of the Modeste FSR bridge, containing multiple cascade steps up to 1m high with deep downstream pools. At the upper end of the site, the channel deflected against steep gully walls. Abundant gravel was present, suitable for adfluvial and resident rainbow trout as well as bull trout. eDNA sample collected.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Surveyed from the Finley FSR downstream to the mapped reservoir location, where the channel retained stream characteristics at the time of assessment. Abundant gravel and cover were present throughout, with numerous run sections providing suitable rearing habitat for juvenile westslope cutthroat trout and rainbow trout. No barriers were observed.  eDNA sample collected.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Landslide ~300m upstream of railway tracks - Wp208. Low gradient stream with abundant gravels and numerous fish to 60mm observed. Entrenched steep wall valley with several sections where clay banks have collapsed into the stream. Surveyed upstream from railway culvert for 650m.  eDNA samples collected upstream of the crossing.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og:
Landslide at 300m upstream of tracks - Wp208

Low gradient stream with abundant gravels and numerous fish to 60 mm observed. Entrenched steep wall Valley with several sections where clay banks have collapsed into the stream. Surveyed to railway Calvert.

properties.comments: Surveyed downstream of railway culvert for ~80m to confluence with the Fraser River. eDNA samples collected upstream of the crossing.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card

properties.comments: Beaver dams ranging from 0.6–1m in height, began approximately 150m downstream of the culvert within an incised gully. Upstream of the dams, abundant gravels, shallow pools, and small woody debris created habitat suitable for parr and juvenile rearing. eDNA samples collected upstream and downstream of the crossing.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Beaverdam’s begin approximately 150 m downstream of the culvert within in sized gully. Damn range in size from .62 near 1 m in height. Upstream of the dance are abundant, gravel, and areas of shallow pool and small wood debris suitable for. Par and juvenile rearing

properties.comments: Moderate-sized, low-gradient stream with abundant gravels and habitat suitable for fry and juvenile salmonid rearing, including shallow pools, small and large woody debris, and undercut banks. No fish or barriers were observed at the time of assessment. eDNA samples collected upstream and downstream of the crossing.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Moderate size stream with abundant gravel and habitat, suitable for fry and juvenile someone rearing with shallow pools, small wood debris, large wood debris, and undercut thanks. Low gradient with no fish and no barriers observed.

properties.comments: The stream was flowing, but discharge appeared minimal relative to channel-forming flows. Extensive algae growth near the highway suggested potential nutrient inputs, possibly from the upstream mill site; algae presence decreased farther downstream. Large areas of gravels were present and suitable for chinook and sockeye spawning, contingent on adequate flows during spawning periods. eDNA sample collected at the downstream end of the survey. Chinook documented downstream of Willow FSR crossing in 2004.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Stream is flowing, but volumes are what must be minimal compared to Channell forming discharge. Very large amounts of algae near to the highway potentially indicating some nutrient inputs perhaps from the mill site upstream however, farther downstream the algae is less thick. Large areas of gravel suitable for Chinook and sockeye spawning if there was sufficient flow during periods of spawning. EDNA site at the bottom end of survey.

properties.comments: Channel was dewatered at the time of assessment with shallow pools present at the downstream end of the site. Gravels were abundant throughout and suitable for chinook and sockeye spawning under adequate flow conditions. Deep pools were likely present when the stream was flowing. Chinook were documented downstream of the Willow FSR crossing in 2004.  eDNA sample collected at the bottom end of the survey (upstream of the crossing).
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Channell D watered at tone assessment, shower pools located at the very downstream end of the site. Abundant gravels throughout suitable for Chinook and sockeye spawning flows were suitable at the time of spawning. Likely some deep pools present when stream is flowing.

properties.comments: Stream was dewatered until approximately 360m upstream of the railway culverts. The farthest downstream pool contained numerous fry and was where eDNA sampling was conducted. Upstream, occasional pools transitioned to increasing flow toward the upper end of the site where a continually flowing channel reemerged. The system was extremely large with high flows during freshet based on the size of the substrates. Gravels were abundant throughout, with limited woody debris or instream cover at low flow, restricted mainly to interstitial spaces between cobbles and boulders.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Stream D watered until approximately 360m upstream of the railway culverts. Farthest downstream pool contained numerous fraud where EDNA sampling was conducted. Upstream of where occasional pools began flows increase towards the top end of the site where continually flowing Channell remerge. This is an extremely large system With high flows and fresh at based on the size of the substrates. Abundant gravels present throughout the entire area with little woody, Dupree and cover present at low flows really only in the interstitial spaces between cobbles and folders.

properties.comments: Abundant gravels were present throughout with no barriers observed between the road crossing and the lake. The stream was relatively large with good flow, containing occasional shallow pools and sparse large and small woody debris. eDNA sample collected at the downstream end of the survey.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Abundant gravels throughout with no barriers between the road and the lake. Larger stream with good flow. Occasional shallow pools and sparse large wood debris and small Woody be thank you.

properties.comments: Low-gradient stream with abundant gravels and diverse cover types including boulders, small and large woody debris, and undercut banks.  Good flow with no natural barriers observed within the surveyed area. eDNA sample was collected at the downstream end of the site. Bull trout documented downstream of the crossing in 2014.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Low gradient stream with abundant gravels and cover available as Boulder‘s smaller debris, large debris, undercut banks, etc. Good flow and no natural barriers observed in area survey

properties.comments: Steep stream with numerous step-pool features formed by large woody debris ranging from 40–60cm in height. Shallow pools were present, typically 30–40cm deep, with boulder and overhead cover distributed throughout. eDNA sample was collected at the downstream end of the site. Bull trout documented downstream of the crossing in 2014.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Nice stream, fairly steep with numerous steps from large Woody debris between 40 to 60 cm in height. Murkiest shallow pools to 30 to 40 cm deep and folder and ledger cover throughout.

properties.comments: Steep stream with good flow and numerous step-pool features ranging from 30–50cm in height. Shallow pools were 30–40cm deep with pockets of gravel suitable for resident Bull trout spawning. Large woody debris was abundant throughout. eDNA sample was collected at the downstream end of the site.
properties.link_method_site_card: Link to Methods for Site Card
properties.assessment_comments_og: Good flow, steeper stream with numerous step pool steps of 30 to 50 cm and shallow pools 30 to 40 cm deep. Pockets of gravel present suitable for resident boat, trout, spawning and abundant large Woody debris throughout.
